html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Italic *agō in non-initial position. Cognate of agō.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /i.ɡoː/, [ɪ.ɡoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /i.ɡo/, [i.ɡɔ] (stressed on the antepenult)

Suffix[edit]

-igō (present infinitive -igāre, perfect active -igāvī, supine -igātum); first conjugation

  2. Enlargement of -ō (suffix forming regular first-conjugation verbs).
    ‎fūmus + ‎-igō → ‎fumigō
    ‎līs (oblique stem: līt-) + ‎-igō → ‎lītigō
    ‎nāvis + ‎-igō → ‎nāvigō
    ‎rēmus + ‎-igō → ‎rēmigō

► Latin words suffixed with -igo (denominative)


References[edit]

  • “-igō¹” on page 825/1 of the Oxford Latin Dictionary (1st ed., 1968–82)

Etymology 2[edit]

A metanalysis of vertex + nasal suffix *-n- > *vertign- > *vertīgin- > vertīgō (“gyration, dizziness”) as vertō (“to turn”) + -īgō. Compare -ūgō (suffix forming nouns).[1]

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈiː.ɡoː/
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈi.ɡo/, [ˈiː.ɡɔ] (stressed on the penult)

Suffix[edit]

-īgō f (genitive -īginis); third declension

  2. Suffixed to nouns and to verbs, forms nouns usually denoting diseased conditions.
    ‎impetō + ‎-īgō → ‎impetīgō
    ‎prūriō + ‎-īgō → ‎prūrīgō
    ‎rōbus + ‎-īgō → ‎rōbīgō
    ‎scaturriō + ‎-īgō → ‎scaturrīgō
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative -īgō -īginēs
Genitive -īginis -īginum
Dative -īginī -īginibus
Accusative -īginem -īginēs
Ablative -īgine -īginibus
Vocative -īgō -īginēs
Derived terms[edit]
► Latin words suffixed with -igo (noun)


References[edit]

  1. ^ Leumann, Manu; Hofmann, Johann Baptist; Szantyr, Anton (1977) Lateinische Grammatik: Lateinische Laut-und Formenlehre, CH Beck, § 325.B.4., page 369
  • “-īgō²” on page 825/1 of the Oxford Latin Dictionary (1st ed., 1968–82)
